title: Ask Riot How You Get That S+ on Urgot

replies.body:
Q. What is in the champ mastery formula
A. Uhh... just play normal

That seriously doesn't help the people asking this question. I don't think it has occurred to Riot that the reason why this is such a popular question is that the grade you receive at the end of the match almost never matches expectations and seems arbitrary. Which is why people want to know what categories to perform well in because playing normally doesn't equate to you getting an S.

Now Riot can keep saying they won't tell anyone because then people will try to play for stats (as if playing for good stats isn't a good thing), but the alternative is people play for stats based on popular theories on what helps. So Riot believes it would be problematic for someone to pick a champ and know what averages they need to beat in order to get an S, and then work toward that goal in game, because maybe someone decides to afk farm for a bit to hit a cs quota. The problem is Riot gives people incentives to care about the ratings and so people will go into games with the end goal of getting an S rather than winning anyway. Only instead of knowing what averages they need to beat, they do the same thing Riot thinks people will only do if they knew the exact formula, which is play for stats that are popularly believed to increase rating. 
An example of this is a recent gbay video where he is trying to get mastery level 7 on irelia. After failing to get an S by playing normally, he looks around for popular theories on what gets you an S and decides to afk farm away from his team as much as possible, and ks at every given opportunity because to the best of his knowledge kills contribute to your rating far better than assists.

So instead of giving people the rubric on what they are being graded on (like any actually legitimate test giver who wants to be taken seriously), people resort to playing for stats regardless if their goal is centered on mastery rank. Only instead of trying to beat an average of 8 kills or something specific for their champion, they will just attempt to ks all game long, or extend the game to farm kills/cs.
Good way to encourage unhealthy gameplay.

EDIT: Glad to see the post generating a discussion (120+ comments so far) but keep in mind a couple things
1. Different roles do in fact have different rating criteria (saw a bunch of comments wondering if this was the case)
2. The issue I mostly discuss in this comment is how despite Riot not divulging the formula, players nonetheless play for stats but to a greater extent than they would if Riot was more transparent.
3. Where I think the system is lacking most and possible change ideas? http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/jUxEs8pi-differences-between-the-champion-mastery-rating-system-and-a-common-academic-grading-system

Adding onto this, as a support main, I'm put into a situation nearly every game where I must choose-- do I save my carry and risk dying? Or since I'm safe, do I just get away to try to get an S? 

Do I leave my ward on cooldown because the jungler was just in top lane and I'm not in any risk of being ganked and should save it until he leaves top lane? Or do I ward every second it's up because that might get me an S? 

My carry and jungler have this kill secured but I want an assist. Do i flash just to get the assist? 

Etc. It's true for every role but especially true for supports because their entire identity is that they give up their own kills, damage, items, etc in favor of the team. Knowing how to get an S would help me play to win and get an S. Maybe it doesn't matter how many times you die as a support as much as we think it does so I can play without limits. 

And besides, knowing how to get an S doesn't mean you'll automatically get one every game. If you need 15 kills for an S then it's still difficult to get those. And killing 15 people will still help you win the game.

Also it seems to me as though riots formula for rating supports isn't optimized. It seems to weigh kills much heavier than assists which is not how a support should usually be played. It encourages supports to KS their carries which is actually detrimental to their chances of winning.

As a player who hasn't had much trouble scoring S grades, I'm going to chime in here (I've managed to score an S+ on a game I lost).

There are tricks that help a player get S grades (I won't reveal the more shady methods).  I will say that the popularized tricks for getting an S generally aren't the right way to go about it.  AFK farming, kill stealing, and other popular notions are flawed methods for achieving an S grade.  You might say you got an S in a game you AFK farmed, but I'm telling you that AFK farming might not have been your best option in that game!

You might think that to get the S grade you have to stat chase.  I often get S grades and I do not stat chase.  I also think that this is really a bad way to go about it and can even hurt your chances.  While I'm on the topic of things that really hurt your chances for an S grade, I'm going to let you know one of the worst ways to hurt your chances of an S grade: dying.  Obviously there is more to getting an S than having 0 deaths, but dying is probably the easiest way to drop your grade to an A+.  You can have a great game, but if you die once to the wrong opponent that can be the difference between an S and an A.
To me this highlights one of the flaws in thinking you have to stat chase to get an S by AFK farming or kill stealing.  Mostly it's the opposite, and not dying is much much more important.

TL;DR If you think you have to stat chase to get an S grade, then rethink your strategy.  It's less about securing stats for yourself and more about making sure you don't give up stats to the opponent.

So, last game, I was Sup and played Janna. I went 0/2/19 in a ~30 minute game (we had 31 kills, so I had assists on 60+%), and 7 cs (because I was actively avoiding getting cs, being a non-Relic using Sup and all).

In a few of my games, some of the supports (you guys are the unsung MVPs) wanted to get S ranks to get to Master 6 or 7, so they wanted to get the last hit on dragon and baron. A bunch of times this led to it getting stolen since the enemy could rush in and smite it down. I'm not blaming them for wanting to get the S ranks, but stuff like that can turn a game easily.

Do you guys think that things would be better if we knew what stats were factored into the formula? Most of my fellow supports have spoken already, and I find myself in the same situation where I can do pretty well in a game, but end up with just a A or A+ sometimes and then B's or S's other times without really understanding what I did better or worse since stats vary so much between games.
This! A thousand times this!

There's a legitimate argument that the transparency of the feedback is too opaque at the moment, especially for players who don't have enough game knowledge to understand where they had a shortcoming.

Frequently, when we see 'I don't understand why I got a (grade)' posts, we'll open it up and see the first response is someone outlining where they fell short. The fact that the player doesn't get this feedback directly is a shortcoming of the system and something we'd like to improve on. We've discussed a few approaches to this, such as possibly showing grades in performance categories. We are not locked into any particular solution yet, but none of the solutions would involve revealing specific stats.

For the most part, we're pretty happy with the grade outputs. In the case of supports however, the grading system is just not great at evaluating game factors correctly atm. We are targeting improvements to support grading with 6.14 and a general upgrade for other positions grade accuracy.

Having performance categories for grades would be extremely helpful. Even showing averages for those categories would be more than fair, and would give a numerical and logical way for people to see what they need to improve on. "Oh, I got 150 CS this game but it says here the average on this champ for roughly this length game in this role is 200...that's probably why I didn't get an A" etc etc. These stats are already used to calculate grades, so why can't they just be displayed?

Say you write a paper for school. You do your best on the paper, only to have it returned with a grade of B, and with no comments explaining what you did poorly enough to not get an A or what you did well enough to not get a C. That doesn't help you write a better essay next time. Feedback is key to improvement, and if the only feedback is "You played well enough to get this grade" then how is one supposed to improve and fix mistakes?

I agree with @senorBunnyRabbit. If the goal of mastery is to make players want to play a champ better, by creating an environment that incentivizes good performance on said champion. It is critical that players receive feedback as to what went well and not so well in the last game. What actions earned them that grade? That is what the champion mastery system lacks, because when players are driven to earn a certain grade but have no idea the specific criteria to earn that grade then they will play not to win the game but to try to get the grade regardless of the win, or getting better at the champion. This unintended affect hurts the community and the game itself.

Direct feedback would be so helpful. There have been countless hours spent frustrated with myself for 
1. Failing to identify my mistakes/weaknesses, and thus, 
2. Failing to correct them. 
Personally, it has definitely been the GREATEST source of tilt and shame. I DESPERATELY AND RUTHLESSLY WANT TO IMPROVE, but don't want to resort to hiring a frigging coach! If I could receive in-client info that helps me identify what to work on, my entire League experience would be monumentally improved.  
This one small change to performance grading would DRASTICALLY increase my enjoyment of the game, thus the amount of time I spend playing it and the potentially increase the amount of money I might (well, most likely, WILL) spend while passionately enjoying one of my favorite hobbies. Do this one thing for us Riot (I say this on behalf of ALL my fellow Lower-ELO Scrublordz), and we will agree to accept that solo-q is most likely maybe (but, hopefully not) dead forever. 
"We Learn More From Our Failures, Than We Do Our Successes"
I can understand not posting the rubric for grades, however, averages for the champ you are playing _After the game_ would be nice.

I agree this would be extremely helpful to have the overall score with the option to see sub-scores for different aspects of the game. Like if CS was low/weak area, then I know to practice last hitting and farming. Or if I'm dying too much,then I would know to play more passively.

Nah, it basically means placing a bunch of wards in your spawn isn't going to help you get a better grade, and chasing the last support kill around the map while your team tries and fails to end because you're 1 kill away from S+ shouldn't be incentivized

We wouldn't know though if it does or doesn't help us get a better grade, or if a single kill on a support is worth more than Nexus destruction or helping end the game participation in your grading. It's all just theorized to be generally KDA, CS, and objective participation because the specifics are left vague. So people going for good grades WILL put priority the above things because we're left ignorant to how it works. And just "playing well" doesn't seem to help a lot of supports, who are expected to place a LOT of wards to help their team. But if placing wards don't count towards your grade (and if they do, do you get more points for warding certain spots, revealing champs in the fog of war with your ward, average pink ward up time?) Then how would you go about figuring out whether or not a support needs double the assists a carry should have in kills to get their S, or if CS matters for them at all? It's all a system with no clear guidelines besides the above "play good" which isn't always true because you're ranked up against people who've played the same champion in the same role, meaning a really good game won't mean jack if it's objectively worse than a series of games with the same setup because a precedent has been set to get that rank after they did. If anything, it seems like abusing off-meta picks with less precedent for their grading would be the way to go with this logic in mind, as the grading criteria has not been set for the champion in the uncommon role.
